entry.title: Re: Settlement periods & Billing Date period of service c...
entry.content:
Why this happens is because, Billing plan = schedule of billing dates and amounts. It doesn‚Äôt change the contract item quantity. Order quantity = the contractual unit (e.g., 1 month). When the invoice request is created, the system copies the item quantity from the contract, not from the billing plan period.

Options to achieve ‚Äú6 months‚Äù on the invoice

Adjust the contract item quantity
Instead of ‚Äú1 month,‚Äù set the item quantity to ‚Äú6 months‚Äù if the billing plan is half‚Äëyearly. The billing plan will then align with the quantity shown on the invoice.

Use Periodic Billing Plans
In the billing plan, you can define the billing rule (e.g., ‚Äúperiodic billing‚Äù). This allows the system to accumulate the billing quantity according to the settlement period (monthly, quarterly, half‚Äëyearly). With proper customizing, the invoice can reflect the total period quantity.

Custom Logic (BAdI)
If you want the system to automatically adjust the billed quantity based on the billing plan period, you can implement a BAdI for billing plan processing. This enhancement can calculate the correct quantity (e.g., 6 months) before the invoice request is created.

entry.title: Table maintenance generator position button question
entry.content:
Hi Friends,

I designed a table and created a table maintenance for it. Now on the initial screen, there's a Position button that let's you locate a record from your table. 1st column (key) works when you type a value to it, it shows what position the record is first found. Now the problem is with 2nd column (key) our analyst said it's not working because when he tried to place an empty first key then placed a value on the 2nd key, he expects the position to show (example 5th record has a match) the 5th record. But based on my investigation, placing a blank first key and a value to the 2nd key tells the program to treat the blank as value therefore combination is 1st key = Blank, 2nd key = value. if it does not exist it won't show a position. the 5th record has a value and not blank.

Example below:

1st key       |       2nd key

001                    1000

002                    2000

003                    3000

004                   4000

005                  5000

Example above, he expects to show position 5 of 5 if you enter first key (blank) and second key 5000. Where in my analysis, it won't point to that position because 5000 has a first key of 005 and not blank. If I place a new entry as 6th row:

(Blank)         5000

Combination 1st key blank and 2nd key 5000 points to position 6 of 6.

Is it possible to point the position to 5 of 6 even if we give blank first key and 5000 second key? I think my analysis is correct.

He's saying why 1st column with value (ex 3) and 2nd column blank points to position 3 of 6?

Hope to get your thoughts on this.

Thank you,

Geoff

entry.title: Violent Geometry of Gold: from Flatlandia to Spacelandia
entry.content:
Let us talk gold.  And Newmont Corp:

Newmont Corporation (stock ticker NEM) is the world‚Äôs largest gold miner.  And one of the top SAP customers.  Same is true for Barrick Mining (B), its competitor and ‚Äì in certain areas ‚Äì a partner.  For example, Barrick-Newmont JV in Nevada is the world‚Äôs largest gold complex.  Barrick is also an SAP customer.

Just to put things in perspective, here is the heat map of the EV for the various players in metals and mining:

 

WHY GOLD RETURNS?  AND PAIRING GOLD-STOCK RETURNS

Recent gold's ascension to unprecedented value prompted many to examine its return dynamics and correlations with various other returns.  We are decided to follow suit.

First, we define returns: stock price changes in NEM and B vs price changes in gold.  Specifically, the raw price data allows us to create time series of returns: first for Newmont Corporation‚Äôs stock and the second for gold.  In both cases, monthly returns are defined as

 

 

 

Dataset: we took 1985-2025 (40 years) gold prices from the World Gold Council (gold.org) and Newmont stock prices (NEM) from Yahoo Finance, turning both into returns.  The resulting data contains 490 monthly returns.

datenem_returngold_return
1985-01-01  
1985-02-01(0.037)(0.011)
1985-03-010.0380.073
1985-04-010.000(0.019)
1985-05-010.0200.020
1985-06-01(0.075)(0.015)
1985-07-010.0720.006
1985-08-010.0110.001
1985-09-01(0.069)0.016
1985-10-010.0590.081
1985-11-010.0760.109
1985-12-01(0.018)0.014
1986-01-010.077(0.061)

And most recent ones:

Let us zoom in on the first pair of returns: 1985 February saw NEM stock price decline by 0.037 and gold decline by 0.011, i.e., the two monthly returns were -0.011 and -0.037 respectively.

Pairing these returns essentially answers the following question: ‚ÄúGiven gold moved by this amount in month t, how did Newmont move in the same month?‚Äù

  • Statistics call this a bivariate observation (or observation from a joint distribution)
  • Finance calls this a paired return realization (or joint asset-factor return where gold is a factor)
  • Mathematically, such paired return is point or vector in, i.e., in two-dimensional space. We will prefer the vector nomenclature here.

With the vector of returns definition in mind, we have the following for February 1985:

 

 

Plotting all such paired returns produces the following scatterplot:

 

As we established, each dot is a vector of returns.  Visually and intuitively, the vector is an arrow starting at the origin [0,0] and extending to such observation coordinates

as shown on the plot below:

 

Put plainly, in February of 1985, both assets - gold and NEM ‚Äì were down, i.e., produced negative returns.  This is why the vector resides in the 3rd quadrant.

What is the magnitude, i.e., length of this vector?

This vector magnitude conveys the length of that month‚Äôs movement, i.e., how large the combined movement was across both gold and Newmont in February 1985.  How ‚Äúviolent‚Äù the month was.

Close up on this vector allows us to see it in greater detail:

 

Specifically, we can visualize the movement: Newmont moved much more down than gold moved left.  This specifically means: both moves into the ‚Äúnegative territory‚Äù but Newmont moved much more. 

We estimate the angle in two ways.

  1. Recalling SOHCAHTOA,

            Since we start from the origin and go counter clock-wise to the red vector, the angle is

 

Put another way, measuring Œ∏ from the positive x-axis, we have tan(Œ∏) = y / x, which captures relative sensitivity of NEM to gold for that month (for that realization only).  This is local sensitivity, not structural beta (yet).

We use -180 degrees to match the polar coordinates. 

  1. Alternatively, using atan2(y, x), the angle naturally places the vector in Quadrant III, confirming a joint negative regime.

Our economic interpretation is simple: the move happened in quadrant III, i.e., negative economic regime (decline for both) and we know that NEM realized over 3x of the gold negative return.

We contrast February 1985 with March, where both Newmont stock and gold went up producing positive returns:

 

Here, the gold went up 2x of NEM. In other words, gold rallied strongly, NEM participated but more conservatively. Therefore,

Angle of 45 degrees would indicate equal movement, but our angle here is only 27.5 degrees which again indicates x-dominated change as opposed to the y-dominated one.  That month, gold won.

In relative magnitude terms.

But what is important for our inference about the relationship is how much gold‚Äôs movement that month ‚Äúshowed up‚Äù in NEM‚Äôs return?  Answer: approximately 50%.  This is where the interpretation becomes interesting since we observe realization of sensitivity.  We are not estimating NEM‚Äôs beta yet; but are observing the sensitivity ‚Äì via vectors.  In other words, we already see some asymmetry: when gold moved down in February, NEM moved down 3x.  When next month gold moved up, NEM moved 0.5x.

So, we can reformulate our findings so far in this way:

We can start generalizing now.

 

HOW MUCH OF NEM‚Äôs MOVEMENT IS EXPLAINED BY GOLD MOVEMENT? 

This question can be reformulated in ‚Äúvector terms‚Äù: what is the projection of the joint NEM/gold return vector onto the gold direction?

We already established that for any given month in our dataset,

Therefore, the gold direction vector is

 

This is a unit vector representing no NEM component.

Now we want to know how much our joint return vector ‚Äì the red arrow ‚Äì projects onto gold. In this particular situation, the case is trivial because the gold resides on x axis and the coordinate 0.073 easily depicts such projection.  However, we want to generalize this rule for the more complicated cases where the factor (e.g., gold) direction vector is not easily located on x-axis.  The projection

 

Where the dot product of this projection is visually intuitive here: hypothenuse * cos (adjacent angle theta) = adjacent side (x coordinate): 

 

 

Note: full dot product identity is

We can verify the 0.073 projection by calculating the dot product:

(r * g) = (0.073, 0.038) * (1, 0) = 0.073 * 1 + 0.038 * 0 = 0.073

Alternatively,

In plain English, the red vector points 0.073 in the gold direction, or the gold-aligned component has magnitude of 0.073.  Financially, we can say that in March 1985, 0.073 of the total movement is explained by gold (that month).

We can now reverse the logic of the dot product definition, or, put another way, we can create a second question:

 

Our first question

 --> Our second question

How much r (i.e., total magnitude of this month‚Äôs combined change) projects onto gold?

What fraction of the total vector‚Äôs length, i.e., ||r|| lies in the gold direction?

Hypothenuse x cos(theta) = adjacent size:

 

 

 

 

 

Scalar ‚Äì in this case length along x axis

Ratio inside the triangle =

 

How many percentage points of this month‚Äôs NEM+gold move lie along gold.

Fraction of the joint vector aligned with gold.  Explanatory share. Early ‚Äúpredecessor‚Äù of R2 in OLS.

Since we asked the question how much the joint movement is gold-aligned, we ought to investigate the other part as well:

 

WHAT HAPPENS TO THE PART WHICH IS NOT GOLD-ALIGNED? 

Financially, this question centers on non-gold, i.e., NEM-idiosyncratic returns (movements in price).  These movements are uncorrelated with the gold movements.  Well, ‚Äúuncorrelated‚Äù applies to the entire data set, so for one month, the lack of relationship here is better explained as orthogonal to the gold direction by construction (uncorrelated only in aggregate).  We define orthogonality month by month; we discover correlation across the entire period.

Let us again use March 1985 since we are familiar with this month‚Äôs returns.  Mathematically, we express the ‚Äúgold unrelated‚Äù NEM movement (return) as orthogonal vector.  In plain English, this is the ‚Äúleftover‚Äù which has zero alignment with gold:

In vector form, this orthogonal vector (perpendicular to the gold projection) is

i.e., difference between two vectors: joint movement vector ‚Äì its projection onto gold.  Why is this vector perpendicular to the ‚Äúgold vector‚Äù?  Because we made gold our explanatory variable.  If we were to use the typical regression language, gold return[s] is the independent (predictor) variables while NEM‚Äôs return[s] is the dependent (predicted) variable.  Clearly, the relationship in reality may be bi-directional and more nuanced, but for now we made ‚Äúan executive decision‚Äù, so to speak: treat gold as the explanatory and NEM as the explained variable (x and y respectively).  This is why the orthogonal vector (blue arrow) is perpendicular to the ‚Äúgold vector.‚Äù

 

Financially,

  • the dotted line vector along the x axis (the ‚Äúgold vector‚Äù) says, ‚ÄúWhat did NEM return because of the gold movement this month?‚Äù (assuming linearity, not causality, and no stability over time)
  • while the vertical blue vector says, ‚ÄúWhat did NEM return that cannot be explained by gold this month?‚Äù

Given this distinction, we can treat the orthogonal (blue) vector as a residual: it provides the gold-unexplained return on the NEM stock. In other words, the projection of the joint vector onto gold represents the gold-explained component of NEM, while the blue vector depicts the gold-unexplained portion of the NEM return.

Now that we defined the joint return vector as

we can plot the gold returns on the x-axis and such residuals on the y-axis:

 

 

Geometry

Mathematics

Statistic

Finance

 

We can see that the residual vectors reside in the direction perpendicular to gold.  We do not see any systematic tilt left: the cloud of the returns is centered on y=0 and appears symmetric.  In other words, we observe typical orthogonality in

 

 

This is the ‚Äúgeometric heart‚Äù of the OLS regression.

 

From construction:

 

By definition of projection (our earlier dot product definition):

 

 

Fitted line is approximately flat, so correlation is

corr(Gold,rt,‚ä•‚Äã)‚âà‚àí0.016

 

 

We estimate beta as:

 

 

This means that when gold moves by 1 unit, NEM moves by 0.075 units.  In other words, +1% gold month corresponds, on average, to +0.075% month for NEM price change. NB! this beta reflects monthly decimal returns and should not be compared directly to conventional annualized betas.

 

Residual:

 

 

 

 

Beta of gold is the systematic gold-driven component of NEM (linear approximation).  This is important for the decision to hedge, increase or decrease gold exposure (via NEM stock), and alleviate macroeconomic shocks.

 

The residual is everything else specific to NEM: mine issues, management decisions and execution, even market noise (equity moves unrelated to gold).

In sum: this plot shows that once we remove the gold-aligned component of NEM‚Äôs returns, what remains is geometrically orthogonal, statistically uncorrelated, and economically idiosyncratic.

 

MANY VECTORS: WHICH ONE BEST DESCRIBES THEM ALL?

 

 

As we established earlier, dot product of two vectors measures how much one vector moves along the other, like joint vector movement along gold we described earlier.  Given we have many joint returns (490 precisely), i.e., vectors v1, v2, ‚Ä¶, vn (depicted in different colors above), how can we find a single direction vector u such that vectors have large projections onto u?  Let us define ‚Äúlarge‚Äù first.

If we sum just the projections, some resulting scalars will have negative sign and some positive, so some positive and negative months would cancel.  We would get ‚Äúnet drift‚Äù but this is a different story.  So, what do we do?

Like we do in estimate variance, we square the projections:

Therefore, we are looking for the unit vector u which maximizes such sum of squares, or ‚Äúsquared projection‚Äù:

 

With the NEM/Gold example, this algorithm chooses a joint Gold‚ÄìNEM movement direction that explains as much total magnitude of monthly co-movement as possible, regardless of the sign.

Here is the resulting projection.  Given the maximization of the ‚Äúsquared projection‚Äù algorithm above, this line has the following meaning: when we orthogonally project all monthly vectors onto this line, the total squared length of those projections is maximized.

 

 

¬∑     Line is almost vertical, which means that NEM returns dominate

¬∑     This is a line, meaning direction +/-u are equivalent: bulls and crashes equally matter

¬∑     Interestingly, our data is clustered around the x axis and is horizontally distributed‚Ä¶ but clustering near the x-axis means large directional alignment with the x-axis, but not necessarily large magnitude-weighted projections: even modest-angle but high-magnitude vertical component yt dominates the squared length (magnitude is quadratic).

In other words, many small calm months near horizontal ‚Äúyield to‚Äù fewer crisis / equity-shock months with large vertical magnitude.

¬∑     Gold moves often, but modestly

¬∑     NEM moves less often, but violently

¬∑     Our algorithm rewards violent months quadratically, i.e., though high energy of such months

These findings may feel counter-intuitive at first, therefore we ought to explore it with the vector magnitudes in mind.

We recall that each joint movement vector (paired return vector which we started with) has the following length, or magnitude:

But we remember that our maximization algorithm squares such vector:

In plain English ‚Äì perhaps not entire correctly but intuitively ‚Äì vector length is the hypothenuse.  Its projection (the adjacent side) is hypothenuse multiplied by cos(angle) ‚Äì this comes from the Pythagorean identity.  But the maximization algorithm, squares such projection (the dot product of v and u above).  The hypotenuse measures how large each vector is but contains no information about orientation, so it cannot distinguish between directions; projections introduce directional dependence, and squaring them yields a rotation-sensitive, non-canceling measure of how much joint movement lies along a candidate direction.

 

Panel 1 on the top plots each vector (i.e., joint movement as a vector from the origin). Most months live in a tight band near zero, but a few months spike dramatically (1987, 1998, 2008, 2015, 2020).

Pane 2 in the middle conveys the energy. Since monthly returns are max 0.77 for NEM and 0.18 for gold, squaring them makes them smaller. But the relative importance of such violent months rises.

Panel 3 conveys that clearly: out of 490 months (40 years of data), just 12 (!) have over a quarter of energy.

Our geometric findings map to the financial interpretation:

  • Most months: small, noisy co-movement between gold and NEM
  • Rare months: systemic stress or regime shifts
    • 1987 crash
    • 1998 LTCM / Russia default
    • 2008 GFC
    • 2020 COVID
  • Those months define the economic meaning of ‚Äújoint movement‚Äù

What surprises me here: though most months cluster near the horizontal axis, a few high-energy months dominate the squared-projection algorithm; consequently, the optimal direction aligns with those violent joint movements rather than with the calm majority.

So, we might have proven that violent / high energy months translate into the near vertical orientation of the optimized line, the line that represents single direction of all 490 vectors.  What does it mean?  It does not mean that gold returns are irrelevant or NEM returns are completely independent.  Rather, we can conclude that the dominant joint-movement direction in 1985-2025 is driven by NEM‚Äôs variability, not by gold‚Äôs average alignment.

The economically meaningful joint shocks between gold and Newmont are equity-driven, not metal-price-driven.

 

CROSS-PRODUCT: WHAT CAN IT TELL US ABOUT NEM AND GOLD?

We will be quickly moving from the ‚ÄòFlatlandia‚Äô (to paraphrase Edwin Abbott) into ‚ÄòSpacelandia‚Äô or into

Let us pick two months: February and March of 1985.  We remember that the joint movement (or joint return) vectors had the following coordinates (see table above):

 

 

Their cross product is defined as

 

We can see this cross product as the 3rd axis vector sticking up, i.e., perpendicular to the plane of the two original vectors. Small red vector here:

 

 

This red upward looking vector is small because we multiply numbers which are each below |1|.  Interestingly, the magnitude of this vector represents the area of the parallelogram formed by the two original vectors,

 

 

 

To check ourselves, let us calculate the area of this parallelogram ‚Äúby hand‚Äù:

  1. Let us find the length of each vector:

    •  

    •  

  2. Now, let us use the green vector as the base. Area of parallelogram is given by the A=base * height where height = slanted side * sin(angle between slanted and base).
    • To find the sine of the angle we use the dot product and then the relationship between the dot product, magnitude, and angle.
    • Dot product is

       

    •  

  1.  

I find it amazing that this barely visible ‚Äúz-axis‚Äù orthogonal vector ‚Äì the cross product of our two Feb and March vectors ‚Äì is indeed the area of the parallelogram formed by the two vectors.

What does the cross-product vector ‚Äì or the parallelogram area ‚Äì mean for NEM and gold?  The magnitude of the orthogonal vector (or area of the parallelogram) represents the joint ‚Äúvolatility‚Äù volume, or the degree of uncorrelated movement between gold and NEM.  Well, more correctly, the area measures directional misalignment x magnitude across two realizations.

The larger the area of such parallelogram (or the height of the orthogonal vector), the more NEM and gold moved freely independently, and the smaller the area, the more they acted ‚Äúin sync‚Äù.  If gold and NEM were perfectly ‚Äúcorrelated‚Äù (this is not correlation yet ‚Äì which requires many observations) during these two months, the parallelogram would collapse into a single line and the orthogonal vector would be zero in length.  Therefore, in such a scenario, a portfolio of two assets ‚Äì NEM and gold ‚Äì would offer no diversification benefit for those realizations.

On the other hand, ideal diversification scenario for these two realizations would be the maximum parallelogram area, where

and the orthogonal vector is maximal in length (magnitude).

 

As a recap for our two asset / two vector situation:

  • Two joint-return vectors (Month 1 and Month 2) form a parallelogram
  • Its area equals the magnitude of the cross product
  • Zero area ‚áî perfect directional alignment
  • Area measures directional change + scale (not correlation in statistics)

Now we can ask ourselves about multiple month pairs within the entire 1985-2025 time horizon: what may the cross product of such pairs tell us? 

 

There is no cross product of the entire period, but we can calculate multiple cross products of month pairs and plot the distribution of such parallelogram areas (aka cross product orthogonal vectors).

 

As a reminder: the smaller the area, the more in sync gold and NEM moved (more colinear) and the larger the area, the more different the returns were: regime break (exogenous events perhaps) and strong directional disagreement / magnitude mismatch.

 

 

 

Rolling 2 adjacent months, i.e., 489 2-month pairs (t, t+1)

All possible month pairs, i.e., 119,805 pairs

How do co-movements (joint returns) for gold and NEM change month to month?

Global cloud geometry

 

 

We see how right skewed data is. Again, many calm months witness relatively ‚Äúsynchronized‚Äù movements of gold and NEM returns (left handside).  But there are ‚Äúviolent‚Äù months where returns are very ‚Äúuncoordinated‚Äù both in direction (angular disagreement) and magnitude.  In sum, the right handside area of this boxplot represent macroeconomic events and market stress.

This full-pair geometry reinforces the same idea, just with many more pairs.

Calm months dominate in count, violent months dominate in impact. 

Consistent with our earlier findings.

 

 

3D ‚ÄúSPACELANDIA‚Äù WITH A 3RD ASSET: WHAT CAN WE LEARN?

First, let us add another company: Barrick Mining.

With this addition, our raw data of returns has one more column:

 

Let us now visualize the 3D space of December 2025:

 

 

 

Here i, j, k denote the standard unit vectors along the Gold (x-), NEM (y-), and Barrick (z-) axes, respectively.

 

 

This single 3D joint-movement vector represents one realization (joint movement returns) in Gold‚ÄìNEM‚ÄìBarrick space.
To examine diversification and independence across the three assets, we zoom in on how such vectors span three-dimensional space across time.

While in Flatlandia (2D) the cross product of two vectors - two joint return vectors for Gold and NEM ‚Äì produced the area of parallelogram (how coordinated or uncoordinated return moves), in Spacelandia (3D), the triple scalar product of three vectors produces the volume of a parallelepiped:

 

 

Thus, this means that now we are looking at three months, e.g., December, November, and October 2025.

In other words,

 

and so on.

 

What does the formula mean geometrically?

‚Äã is vector perpendicular to the plane spanned by

 

  • Its magnitude

  •  

     is the area of the parallelogram built on

  •  

  • Then

  •  

     takes the component of

  •  

    ‚Äã in the perpendicular direction, i.e., ‚Äúheight‚Äù
  • So, volume = base area √ó height.

 

 

 

 

What does ‚Äúbig vs small volume‚Äù mean financially?  How many independent directions did the system move across those 3 months.

  • Volume ‚âà 0: the 3 monthly joint-movement vectors are nearly coplanar / linearly dependent.
    Across these three months, the Gold‚ÄìNEM‚ÄìBarrick system mostly moved in one common pattern; nothing ‚Äònew‚Äô happened in the 3-asset relationship.
  • Large volume: the three months span a genuinely 3D chunk of space.
    Across these three months, the relationship among Gold, NEM, and Barrick produced a new linearly independent shock pattern‚Äîthese assets did not just scale up/down together; their co-movement structure shifted.

Like we did in the Flatlandia with the cross products across the entire time period (490 months ‚Äì 1 because of rolling adjacent 2-month convention), for Spacelandia, we can perform the same for the rolling adjacent 3 month parallelepiped volumes:

 

 

We observe somewhat similar picture: there are a lot of calm months where the volume of the RD parallelepiped is small (joint return movements appear synchronized in direction and magnitude) and there are ‚Äúviolent‚Äù months where such joint return movements are misaligned in direction and magnitude (volume of the resulting parallelepiped is high).

 

Finance Color #1: It clicked: diversification is episodic, not average

Our geometry shows that diversification between gold and mining equities (NEM and B) is state-dependent, not constant:

  • Most months: small areas / volumes ‚Üí assets behave as if driven by a common macro regime
  • Rare months: large areas / volumes ‚Üí diversification suddenly becomes real

Therefore,

  • long-run correlations look ‚Äúmoderate‚Äù
  • but portfolio protection often shows up only during stress

In other words, this geometry captures when diversification matters, not just whether it exists on average.

Finance Color #2: Volumes identify regime transitions, not just volatility

This is the ‚Äúvalue add‚Äù by geometry:

  • Large magnitudes = volatility
  • Large areas = change in pairwise structure
  • Large volumes = change in system structure

So, a large rolling 3-month volume is not ‚Äújust a volatile period‚Äù ‚Äî it is a period in which the relationship among Gold, Newmont, and Barrick itself changed.  Financial models break down, hedging become unstable, new factors emerge and/or replace previous ones.

As an extra step, I re-examined the history of various events ‚Äúsurrounding‚Äù such extreme returns on the right handside.  Picking just a few of those located on the most far end of the x-axis, yields the following picture and details below:

Rare large-volume rolling 3-month windows (chronological)

1986-04 ‚Üí 1986-06

  • Macro / markets: Post-Volcker disinflation environment (CPI in us at 10-14% so Feds increased the rate beyond 20%); USD strength and falling inflation expectations.
  • Gold: Weak and unstable price action as real rates rose.
  • Miners: Equity-specific adjustments amplified moves relative to gold.
  • Why volume spikes: Gold and miners responded differently to shifting rate expectations, breaking the usual ‚Äúgold proxy‚Äù behavior.

1987-08 ‚Üí 1987-10

  • Macro / markets: Lead-up to and aftermath of the October 1987 stock market crash (on Oct 19, 1987 Dow Jones lost 22%).
  • Gold: Initially mixed, then benefited as a crisis hedge.
  • Miners: Extreme equity volatility dominated fundamentals.
  • Why volume spikes: Equity shock introduced a new independent direction orthogonal to gold‚Äôs behavior.  Liquidity ‚Äúevaporated‚Äù so the correlation is almost 1.

1998-08 ‚Üí 1998-10

  • Macro / markets: Russian default (domestic debt and subsequent ruble devaluation) + Long-Term Capital Management crisis (ironically, LTCM, a hedge fund, was founded by Nobel Prize laureates in Economics including Robert Merton and Myron Scholes); severe global risk aversion.
  • Gold: Safe-haven demand surged after prolonged weakness.
  • Miners: Sharp equity dislocations due to leverage and funding stress.
  • Why volume spikes: Breakdown of historical gold‚Äìminer co-movement during systemic stress.

1999-09 ‚Üí 1999-11

  • Macro / markets: Late-cycle equity exuberance (NASDAQ is in vertical ascent) approaching dot-com peak.  Traditional valuations? Dismissed.
  • Gold: Structural weakness, including sales (not purchases!) by Central banks.
  • Miners: Equity market forces overwhelmed commodity linkage.  They traded like ordinary stocks rather than gold-linked assets.
  • Why volume spikes: Miners decouple from gold amid speculative equity flows.

2008-09 ‚Üí 2008-11/12 ‚Üí 2009-02

  • Macro / markets: Systemic collapse after Lehman, followed by rapid stabilization via extraordinary monetary intervention.
  • Gold: Immediate safe-haven surge during panic, then sustained strength as QE and monetary debasement expectations formed.
  • Miners: Initial collapse with equities despite rising gold, followed by a violent rebound once equity markets stabilized.
  • Why volume spikes: Two-phase regime shift ‚Äî first forced deleveraging overrides gold linkage, then re-alignment as the system transitions into a new equilibrium.

2016-01 ‚Üí 2016-03 ‚Äî Global growth scare ‚Üí commodity & gold rebound

  • Macro / markets: Early-2016 global risk-off driven by an oil collapse (oil drops to some $26/barrel ‚Äì lowest in a decade), China growth fears, and recession concerns; sentiment stabilized by March.  Feds: in late 2015 raise rates to 0.5% first time since 2006 (akin to ‚Äúemergency policy is about to end‚Äù)
  • Gold: Strong rally as investors sought safety and repriced lower real rates.
  • Miners: Sharp rebound as gold surged and balance-sheet fears eased.  Both NEM and B enter 2016 deeply out of favor. Had spent years cutting costs, selling assets, and repairing balance sheets.
  • Why volume spikes: Sudden regime shift ‚Äî from deflation panic to reflation relief ‚Äî forced rapid repositioning in gold and mining equities.

These simple bullet points provide just some color to how high can the volumes go.  As a reminder: the volumes here (triple scalar product) represent how different the returns were.  Large volumes - the outliers we discuss ‚Äì indicate situations where gold returns continued but NEM and B returns changed drastically; key is that these returns moved differently relative to each other.

 

RECAP: GEOMETRY = FRIEND OR FOE?

In this note we examined the relationship between gold and Newmont returns through a geometric lens, gradually expanding the dimensionality of analysis.  Then we added Barrick returns and therefore examined even more nuanced interplay of gold and equities as well as time (regimes such as calm months vs. economic and market stress).

First came monthly gold‚ÄìNewmont returns as joint movement vectors in two-dimensional space.  Vector projections allowed decomposing each month‚Äôs movement into a gold-aligned component and an orthogonal component.  This orthogonal residual is geometrically perpendicular to the gold direction by construction, statistically uncorrelated in aggregate, and economically interpretable as NEM-specific behavior (e.g., disposition of a mine, acquisition, or any other NEM-specific and gold-agnostic corporate and market factor).  This construction reveals the geometric foundation of linear regression without invoking probabilistic assumptions.

Moving beyond individual months: many joint-return vectors simultaneously allow ‚Äì via the maximized squared projections direction - showing that a small number of high-energy months dominate the long-run joint behavior of gold and Newmont (joint return-wise).  Calm months are numerous but economically secondary; crisis periods define the dominant co-movement structure.

The cross product starts bridging Flatlandia to Spacelandia allowing to examine how joint return behavior changes across time. The area of the parallelogram formed by two monthly joint-movement vectors - or the resulting orthogonal vector magnitude - captures directional misalignment and scale across realizations.  Rolling and global distributions of these areas reveal a strongly right-skewed structure: most months are synchronized, while rare episodes reflect regime breaks and stress.  Calm months dominate in count; violent months dominate in impact.  In a sense, the newly formed ‚Äúz-axis‚Äù cross-product confirms the findings of the [purely 2D] squared projections.

Adding Barrick Mining price moves turns this into the 3D ‚ÄúGold‚ÄìNewmont‚ÄìBarrick space.‚Äù  Here, diversification and independence are no longer captured by areas but by volumes, measured via the scalar triple product of three joint-movement vectors.  Rolling three-month volumes quantify whether the system behaves as effectively two-dimensional or explores genuinely three-dimensional dynamics.  Periods of large volume correspond to shifts in the joint structure of returns rather than simple increases in volatility.  Our findings here are consistent with those above (projections and cross-products):

The economic meaning of gold‚Äìmining equity (NEM an B) relationships is defined not by average behavior, but by rare, high-energy episodes in which co-movement geometry changes.  Vector geometry provides a unified language to describe projection, residuals, regime shifts, and diversification in a way that is intuitive, rigorous, and directly interpretable for financial decision-making.

Perhaps this picture for the 24 years of the market from Visual Capitalist (link) provides an independent validation for our findings:

 

 

ANOTHER RECAP: ‚ÄúSO WHAT‚Äù REGARDING THE VECTORS AS ANALYTICAL TOOLS?

Throughout the analysis, it was becoming clearer to me that, on one hand, findings from the previous layer of complexity ‚Äì e.g., projections and simple orthogonal vector ‚Äì repeated with the next level of complexity.  So, the question becomes, ‚ÄòWhy go to another level of complexity then?‚Äù  On the other hand, certain additional insights emerge with the growing complexity and increasing dimensionality of the analyses (from ‚ÄòFlatlandia‚Äô to ‚ÄòSpacelandia‚Äô).

This table attempts to summarize the incremental value of the growing dimensionality: from ‚Äúsimple 2D‚Äù to ‚Äútransitional 2D‚Äù (cross product and resulting orthogonal vector) to the ‚Äúfull 3D‚Äù:

 

Layer / Tool

Dimensional Regime

Mathematical Object

What It Measures (Plain English)

What It Adds Beyond Previous Layer

Concrete Insight in This Note

Executive-Level ‚ÄúSo What‚Äù

Vector Projection (starting point)

1D (within 2D space)

 

How much a month aligns with the main co-movement direction

Establishes baseline linear relationship

Most months weakly aligned; few dominate

‚ÄúMost months don‚Äôt move the needle.‚Äù

Squared Projection

1D (within 2D space)

 

Energy contributed along that direction

Removes sign noise; highlights dominance

Tail months dominate total energy

‚ÄúRisk contribution is extremely uneven over time.‚Äù

Orthogonal Component

2D (full plane)

 

How much of the move cannot be explained by the main relationship

Separates expected vs. unexpected behavior

Large deviations cluster in turbulent periods

‚ÄúThis is when the hedge breaks down.‚Äù

Cross Product (Area)

Bridge: 2D ‚Üí 3D

 

Month-to-month instability in direction & magnitude

Introduces dynamics and curvature

Right-skewed: calm regimes, violent breaks

‚ÄúRelationships don‚Äôt drift ‚Äî they snap.‚Äù

Scalar Triple Product (Volume)

True 3D space

 

Whether movements require three independent dimensions

Tests incremental diversification

Large volumes occur only in crisis windows

‚ÄúThe third asset matters only under stress.‚Äù

What feels like increasing mathematical complexity may be a controlled expansion of dimensional freedom.  

  • Earlier tools deliberately restrict the analysis to one direction inside a plane: is there a dominant relationship at all?
  • Orthogonal components then allow full 2D freedom: when does that relationship fail?
  • The cross product is the bridge‚Äîwhile still living in 2D, it produces a vector that points out of the plane, signaling instability and curvature over time.
  • Finally, the scalar triple product moves fully into 3D, asking the hardest question: do three assets truly span independent risk space, or are they effectively planar?

I expected the higher dimensionality tools to overturn some earlier results.  But they kept confirming them.  Perhaps the fact that all layers of complexity for all assets ‚Äì gold, NEM and Barrick - converge on the same story is actually a sort of validation.  Each added dimension removes a potential excuse: ‚Äúit‚Äôs just linear,‚Äù ‚Äúit‚Äôs just volatility,‚Äù ‚Äúit‚Äôs just scale.‚Äù  Remaining is a conclusion: risk, instability, and diversification all concentrate in rare, high-stress episodes.  This is the insight from 40 years of gold, NEM and B returns.

entry.title: Re: Issue with Facebook login via mobile browser
entry.content:
There is a known issue with Facebook login in the popup.  It happens because Facebook has started adding new security headers that block pop-ups from being communicated from cross-origin parent windows, which eventually prevents popups from closing and notify parent windows that a session was created.

Note:  These headers are not present all the time or not on all Facebook URLs, so the issue does not always reproduce.

Solution:

Make sure to implement social login with the authFlow: "redirect" parameter that can be invoked through either:

  • the global WebSDK Configuration,
  • the accounts.showScreenSet JS WebSDK method,
  • or the accounts.socialLogin JS Web SDK method

depending on what aligns best with your current implementation.

The default flow - authFlow: "popup" - does not work well in mobile browser environments due to different handling of cookies, iFrames, etc. that our Web SDK depends on. CNAME and Custom API Domain setup is required when using authFlow: "redirect".

Documentation:

3422488 - Facebook social login from a browser on mobile devices does not work - SAP for Me

3328279 - Error during first login with Facebook on mobile devices (Android and iOS) - SAP for Me

accounts.socialLogin JS | SAP Help Portal

entry.title: EWM: How to determine HU/Packing status before Set Ready for Shipment to avoid printing duplicate
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We are working on an SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud EWM scenario with Goods Issue (GI) label printing and are facing a challenge related to duplicate label generation.

Current Process

  • GI labels are printed during the packing process in EWM, triggered by the Warehouse Task Confirmed event.
  • During packing:
    • An internal Warehouse Task (WT) is created
    • GI label is printed based on the WT number
    • A Handling Unit (HU) is created as part of the packing process

      New Requirement

      • Print the GI label at the Set Ready for Shipment stage using the Outbound Delivery Change event.
      • This should happen only for deliveries that are not packed into an HU.

        Issue

        • When the delivery is set to Ready for Shipment, GI labels are also getting printed for deliveries that are already packed in HU, resulting in duplicate label printing.

          Analysis Done

          • We explored checking the packing status (HU existence) using:
          • I_OutboundDelivery 
          • I_OutboundDeliveryItem 
          • However, since packing and label printing are executed within EWM, these CDS views are not updated in real time during the packing process.
          • We also could not find any EWM-specific CDS views that reliably expose real-time packing or HU status.

            Question
            Is there a recommended or alternative approach in EWM to reliably determine whether:

            • Packing has already been completed, or
            • An HU already exists for the delivery
              before triggering GI label printing at the Set Ready for Shipment stage, so that duplicate printing can be avoided?

              Any guidance on best practices, EWM events, APIs, CDS views, or extensibility options would be highly appreciated.

              Thanks in advance for your support

              •

entry.title: Re: Differences between SAP ECC and S/4 HANA in HCM
entry.content:
SAP HCM Integration with SuccessFactors: Details, Licensing & Benefits

Integration Overview

SAP HCM integration with SuccessFactors represents a strategic transition from on-premise HR systems to cloud-based Human Experience Management (HXM). This integration enables organizations to maintain their existing SAP HCM infrastructure while leveraging SuccessFactors' advanced cloud capabilities for enhanced employee experiences and modern HR processes.

The integration supports multiple deployment scenarios including side-by-side HCM, core hybrid HCM, and full migration approaches, allowing organizations to choose the path that best fits their business requirements and timeline .

Integration Details

Technical Integration Components

The integration utilizes middleware solutions, particularly SAP Cloud Integration, to facilitate seamless data exchange between SAP HCM and SuccessFactors modules. Key integration scenarios include:

  • Employee Data Integration: Bidirectional synchronization of employee master data between systems
  • Compensation Data Transfer: Extract compensation data from SAP S/4HANA and transfer to SuccessFactors for planning, then return planned data for payroll processing
  • Recruiting Data Integration: Seamless flow of candidate and hiring data between recruiting and core HR systems
  • Variable Pay Data: Integration of variable compensation components across systems
Data Migration & Mapping
  1. Employee Master Data Transfer: Core employee information, personal data, and employment relationships
  2. Organizational Structure Mapping: Cost centers, organizational units, and reporting hierarchies,
  3. Payroll and Compensation Data: Salary structures, benefits, and compensation planning data
  4. Time and Attendance Records: Working time data, absences, and time sheet information.
System Architecture Post-Integration

The integrated architecture maintains SAP HCM as the system of record for certain processes while leveraging SuccessFactors for talent management, performance, and employee experience functions. This hybrid approach ensures data consistency while enabling modern HR capabilities.

Licensing Structure

SuccessFactors Module Licensing
Module License Type Features Included
Employee CentralPer employee/monthCore HR data management, organizational structure
Performance & GoalsPer employee/monthPerformance evaluations, goal setting, talent management
Learning ManagementPer employee/monthTraining programs, development planning, compliance tracking
Recruiting ManagementPer employee/monthTalent acquisition, candidate management, recruiting marketing
Compensation ManagementPer employee/monthCompensation planning, pay equity analysis
OnboardingPer employee/monthNew hire processes, integration workflows
Additional Licensing Considerations

Organizations considering integration should note that maintaining both SAP HCM and SuccessFactors could require multiple licenses including "BizX, WFA, Fiori, HCM, ESS/MSS, Payroll, BI/BO, HANA, EFM" depending on desired functionality. For GROW with SAP customers, a "GROW with SAP, core HR add-on" provides integrated SuccessFactors capabilities with additional licensing costs.

Cost Factors
  • Company size and employee count directly impact subscription costs
  • Geographic deployment affects pricing due to regional compliance requirements
  • Integration complexity and customization needs influence implementation costs
  • SAP Cloud Platform Integration is included with People Central Hub subscriptions

Benefits of HCM Implementation

Operational Benefits
  1. Streamlined HR Processes: Unified platform for all HR functions from recruiting to retirement
  2. Automated Workflow Management: Cross-system workflows that harmonize processes across hybrid landscapes
  3. Reduced Manual Data Entry: Automated data synchronization between systems
  4. Improved Compliance Tracking: Built-in compliance features for global regulations including GDPR
Strategic Benefits
  • Enhanced Employee Experience: Modern, intuitive interfaces with mobile accessibility
  • Better Talent Management: Integrated performance, learning, and development capabilities
  • Data-Driven Decision Making: Advanced analytics and reporting across all HR functions
  • Scalability for Business Growth: Cloud-based architecture supports organizational expansion
Financial Benefits
  • Cost Reduction: Lower total cost of ownership through cloud delivery model
  • Efficiency Gains: Streamlined processes reduce administrative overhead
  • ROI Realization: Improved productivity and reduced manual processes deliver measurable returns
Technology Benefits
  • Cloud-Based Accessibility: Secure, scalable access from anywhere
  • Mobile Workforce Enablement: Native mobile applications for HR tasks
  • Integration Capabilities: Seamless connection with other SAP and third-party systems
  • Continuous Innovation: Regular updates and new features delivered quarterly

Implementation Considerations

Organizations should plan for comprehensive change management, including user training and adoption strategies. The integration timeline varies based on complexity, but the modular approach allows for phased implementation. Risk mitigation includes thorough testing of data synchronization and maintaining backup systems during transition periods.

Success Metrics

Key performance indicators include user adoption rates, process efficiency improvements, data accuracy metrics, and cost savings realization. Organizations typically measure success through reduced time-to-hire, improved employee satisfaction scores, and decreased HR administrative costs.

Regards,

Bharanidharan S P M

entry.title: Which types of quotations and number of records are supported by the "Import Sales Quotations" app
entry.content:
Hello SAP Experts

Our business requirement is that we need to export a huge number of Sales Quotations in the "Import Sales Quotations" app however, we are in doubt about:

  1. Which type of quotation is supported in the application?
  2. How many quotations can I import at the same time?

 

Thank you for your help


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Which types of quotations and number of records are s...
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community

The app "Import Sales Quotations" app supports quotations that belong to the type B (Quotation):

Example Sales Document Type - QT

 

Pay attention to the current constraints of the application:

  • The app supports a limited number of sales quotation types:

    • Quotation types must belong to document category B (Quotation).

    • Sales quotations do not have to be created with reference to a preceding document.
       Note

      Key users can query whether a reference document is mandatory for quotation creation by checking the configuration of a sales quotation type. To do so, open the Configure Sales Document Types configuration activity in your configuration environment.

  • This app does not support one-time customers or configurable products (that is, configurable materials).

SAP Recommendation is to import 1000 records per import, the data limits are defined in SAP backend and are shared across all SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition users, to ensure network stability and performance to everyone, those values are not editable.
More detailed information can be checked in the official SAP Help Portal app documentation:
  • Import Sales Quotations

Kind regards

entry.title: Re: Count on fiori Iview
entry.content:
@rajeshkumarp Service URL Parameter Configuration

For displaying workitem count on your My Inbox Fiori iView tile in SAP Portal, you need to configure the correct Service URL parameter. Based on your specific scenario, use one of the following Service URL formats:

Standard My Inbox Count Service URL

/sap/opu/odata/IWPGW/TASKPROCESSING;v=2;mo/TaskCollection/$count/?$filter=Status eq 'READY' or Status eq 'RESERVED' or Status eq 'IN_PROGRESS' or Status eq 'EXECUTED'

Alternative Service URL Format

If the above doesn't work, try:

/sap/opu/odata/IWPGW/TASKPROCESSING;v=2;mo/ItemcountCollection/$count

The key difference is using ItemcountCollection/$count instead of TaskCollection/$count.

Unit Label Configuration

For the Unit Label parameter, you should configure:

  • Unit Label Value: Enter a descriptive label such as:
    • Items - for general workitem count
    • Tasks - for task-specific count
    • Workitems - for workflow items
    • Leave blank if you prefer no unit label display

The unit label appears below the count number on the tile to provide context for users.

Troubleshooting Steps

Step 1: Verify Service URL Format

  1. Ensure the Service URL includes the complete path with /$count parameter
  2. Check that the filter conditions match your workitem statuses
  3. Test the URL directly in browser to verify it returns a numeric count

Step 2: Check Portal Configuration

  1. Access your Portal iView configuration
  2. Navigate to the tile properties section
  3. Verify the Service URL field contains the complete OData endpoint
  4. Ensure no truncation occurs in the URL field

Step 3: Validate OData Service Response

The service should return a simple numeric count. Test the URL:

https:///sap/opu/odata/IWPGW/TASKPROCESSING;v=2;mo/TaskCollection/$count/?$filter=Status eq 'READY' or Status eq 'RESERVED' or Status eq 'IN_PROGRESS' or Status eq 'EXECUTED'

Regards,

Bharanidharan S P M

entry.title: Re: How to Track ETC and Plan Changes for Audit Trail in...
entry.content:
Good day @SVops 

Thank you for your question. See my response to each question below.

  1.   Is there a standard way to view change history for ETC and Plan values in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition?

Yes, in public cloud a standard audit trail for Customer Projects is available through Display Change Documents (also known as Show Change Documents).  

For your Customer Projects you can use these change documents, which is also the key for ETC and plan related audit:

  • Change Document for Commercial Project Header
  • Change Document for Commercial Project Financial Plans.
  • Chang Document for Commercial Project Roles and staffing.

See KBA 2913110 and Displaying Changes in Objects in Customer and Internal Project Management for more details.

  1. Can we access this information through Released CDS views?

There is no released CDS like I_ChangeDocument and I am not aware of any released CDS you can use for this in public cloud. See KBA 3337092 for more insights.

So, for audit evidence, i suggest you use the Display Change Documents app export and not CDS

Should you auditors require more details, you can use Display Security Audit Log. This is more complementary; it does not replace change documents.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP Cloud Connector Adding subaccount -Proxy cannot b...
entry.content:
Hi

The easiest is to use the authentication data that you can download from "connectivity/cloud connector". On top of the page, there is a blue button "Download authentication data". Then, on the SAP CC side, click "+ add subaccount" and choose the second option: "Configure using authentication data".

Select "Add subaccount authentication data from file" then select the downloaded file using the browse button.

 

That's it !

I just did it a few minutes ago with a trial account, and it works as expected.

Julien / Codilog

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: SAP Joule for Developers, Hobbies Series and Upcoming Events!
entry.content:
We‚Äôre happy to bring you another edition filled with highlights, stories, and updates from across our global SAP Community.

There is so much happening right now: from innovative blog posts and hands-on technical content to inspiring personal stories and exciting upcoming events around the world!

In this edition, we explore practical resources to support your SAP BW to SAP Datasphere journey, dive into AI-enabled development with ABAP and Joule, discover a beautiful story from our Hobbies Series, and of course, share important community news and events you won‚Äôt want to miss.

Let‚Äôs dive in! 

Featured Blog Posts 

Support with functionalities from SAP BW system to SAP Datasphere 

With the end of SAP BW approaching, many companies and developers are diving into SAP Datasphere to migrate reports and build new solutions. In this blog post, based on hands-on implementation experience, SAP member Christian Gravesen, focuses on one specific gap: the absence of standard BW exit variables like Current Month and Current Year in Datasphere. He presents a ready-to-install package that recreates these calendar variables, complete with GitHub access and clear installation guidance. This is a practical resource for anyone working on BW migrations or developing analytical models in SAP Datasphere. 

Read Christian Gravesen blog post here 

AI Enabled Application with ABAP AI SDK powered by ISLM 

As AI becomes a core part of application development, SAP Joule for Developers introduces AI-driven capabilities directly into the ABAP world. In this blog post, SAP¬¥s  Swathy explains how to move beyond traditional transactional scenarios by using the ABAP AI SDK powered by Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management (ISLM) to build AI-enabled applications. Through her example (generating a travel itinerary and budget breakdown using generative AI), she walks through the supported products, architecture, and key implementation steps. The ABAP AI SDK powered by ISLM is available in SAP BTP ABAP; SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and Cloud Private Edition. Additionally, if you want to keep updated about ABAP AI, there is a list of blog posts thread that you can subscribe to. 

Read Swathy blog post here 

SAP Joule Skill in SAP EHSM- Incident Management and more 

Since the beginning of this year, SAP community member Pardhasaradhi started posting great content about his SAP Joule learning and execution journey. One of his recent blog posts about SAP Joule Skill in SAP EHSM-Incident Management, he gives details about low-code and even no-code setup using OData Service. From understanding Joule capability types to configuring, deploying, and testing a custom skill, the blog provides a clear, practical guide for enabling conversational, AI-driven incident reporting in an enterprise environment. And because he is a highly active member on blogging, we highly recommend following his latest posts to keep learning about SAP Joule Skills in Asset Management Space and more! 

Read Pardhasaradhi Reddy Chelikam blog post here 

Automated Predictive Library (APL) Forecast in a Seamless Planning Model 

SAP¬¥s Max Gander and Marc Daniau recently published a very complete guide on how predictive forecasts built with SAP HANA‚Äôs Automated Predictive Library (APL) can be integrated into a seamless planning model. They explained that now with‚ÄØSAP Business Data Cloud‚ÄØand seamless planning,‚ÄØdata scientists‚ÄØcan now‚ÄØleverage‚ÄØHANA‚Äôs‚ÄØPredictive‚ÄØAnalysis Library (PAL) and Automated Predictive Library (APL)‚ÄØdirectly on the‚ÄØHANA‚ÄØdatabase of SAP Datasphere and nicely integrate the results into planning processes.‚ÄØIn the step-by-step guide, it is possible to visualize the full architecture, from building the forecast directly in HANA, orchestrating it via task chains in SAP Datasphere, and finally consuming the results as a live version in SAP Analytics Cloud. In the end, they recommend more useful content published in SAP Community. This is a definitely must-read. 

Read Max Gander and Marc Daniau blog post here 

Community News 

Don¬¥t forget, we are still waiting for your feedback!  

In the last Community Voice edition, we explained details about our 2026 SAP Community open survey. For more details, please check‚ÄØMynyna¬¥s‚ÄØBlog Post here, but we would like to remind everyone that there is still time to participate and give your opinion. The survey takes just a few minutes of your time and can be completed from your smartphone or computer.‚ÄØOnce the survey concludes, we will carefully analyze the results and share a report summary with you.‚ÄØ‚ÄØIf you‚ÄØshare the survey link / QR-Code in‚ÄØyour‚ÄØsocial media and comment‚ÄØon the blog post‚ÄØwith a link to your post that shows how you helped spread the word, you are automatically participating into a draw to win a‚ÄØvirtual‚ÄØmeet & greet with Josh Bentley, head of SAP Community! 

Click here to participate on the survey  

Hobbies Series:‚ÄØTerrace Gardening  

SAP‚Äôs Sumaiya recently shared her journey into gardening in the SAP Community Hobbies Series. A hobby that began simply and grew into a thriving terrace garden with over 300 plants, including fruits, vegetables, succulents, and ornamental species. She describes how gardening became a way to slow down, reconnect, and find balance beyond screens and schedules. Through her story, Sumaiya reflects on the lessons gardening has taught her, from patience and consistency to embracing challenges like weeds and pests with natural, sustainable solutions. In the end, she concludes with a parallel between gardening and the SAP world, highlighting how gardening reminds us that real success comes from nurturing systems patiently, not forcing outcomes, which helps her show up at work more grounded, focused, and calm. Besides the beautiful pictures she shared of her flowers, we were more than delighted to learn how this hobby has had such an impact on her life. 

Read Sumaiya blog post here 

Events 

Upcoming SAP CodeJam¬¥s  

This year events have officially started, and one of the greatest opportunities to have a hands-on learning experience is definitely through an SAP CodeJam. Around the world, our Developers team gives their best to bring their expertise and share useful tips on various SAP topics. Check bellow the list of the upcoming SAP CodeJam for the next 2 weeks:  

  • Milan, Italy - Joule Studio: Create Joule Skills and Agents ... - SAP Community 
  • Sydney, Austrakua -  Joule Studio: Create Skills and Agents to Ext... - SAP Community 
  • Pune, India - Getting started with Generative AI Hub on SAP... - SAP Community 
  • Heidelberg. Germany - SAP Build: Create Event-Based Processes (Heid... - SAP Community 
  • Pune, India - Build AI services using the CAP and Generativ... - SAP Community 
  • Paris, France - Joule Studio: Create Joule Skills and Agents ... - SAP Community 
  • Melbourne, Australia - Joule Studio: Create Skills and Agents to Exte... - SAP Community 
  • Brisbane, Australia - Gen AI Hub & Joule Studio : Create Skills and... - SAP Community 
  • Paris, France - Real-time data for AI agents: Grounding with ... - SAP Community 

SAP Inside Track Joinville 2026 

Are you part of the Joinville community group? Or maybe you live nearby? One of the biggest events of the year is coming up: SAP Inside Track Joinville 2026! You can expect high-level sessions on innovation, technology, and SAP trends, opportunities to exchange experiences with other community experts, and qualified networking with companies and professionals from the region. The event will take place on March 14 at √Ågora Tech Park, Joinville. Make sure to secure your spot and get your tickets through sympla. And follow the Joinville Group to have access to all the updates and news! 

Read more details in Juliane Schmitzhaus blog post here

entry.title: PPDS: Programmatic conversion of Planned Order to Production Order-ORDER_NOT_FOUND outside standard
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am working on SAP APO / PPDS and trying to programmatically convert a PPDS planned order to a production order.

In the standard transaction (e.g. /SAPAPO/RPP7), the conversion works correctly. However, when I try to trigger the same logic from a custom ABAP program, I consistently receive the exception ORDER_NOT_FOUND.

I am currently calling the following function module
/SAPAPO/RRP_ORDER_SET_CNVIN

Observations
The same order exists and converts successfully when executed via the standard PPDS transaction.
The FM throws ORDER_NOT_FOUND when called from:
SE37
A custom Z-report
Some function modules mentioned online (e.g. order read helper FMs) do not exist in our APO release, suggesting a class-based PPDS runtime.
Understanding so far
It seems that standard PPDS transactions implicitly:

Initialize the planning context (planning version, session, liveCache)
Load the order into the PPDS buffer
Work with the internal PPDS ORDERID (GUID) rather than an external/display order number
Whereas in a custom program, this context is not initialized automatically, leading to ORDER_NOT_FOUND.

Questions
What is the SAP-recommended API (FM or class) to:
Retrieve the internal PPDS ORDERID
Convert a planned order to a production order programmatically?
What is the minimum required planning context initialization needed before calling the conversion logic?
Is there a released and supported approach for background/mass conversion outside the PPDS UI?
Any guidance, sample code, or SAP Notes would be highly appreciated.

Thanks in advance.

entry.title: Looking to extend the Capacity Planning applications?
entry.content:
The Fiori apps like Capacity Scheduling Table, and Capacity Scheduling Board support UI-level extensibility, that will allow key users and functional experts to add custom fields and filters using key user extensibility features without writing custom code or requiring in-depth technical knowledge, I will introduce the possible changes by using application:

- Custom Fields

- Manage Characteristic as Custom Fields 

Before starting, lets introduce the Business Context available for each application:

1. On Capacity Scheduling Board: You can easily adjust the Order Details displayed and the Operation Info once adjusting elements of UI Technology using Business context: Master Data: Product General and Master Data: Product Plant to add fields

After adjustments you can follow the following Navigation Path to select your new Custom Fields

  • Capacity Scheduling Board app > Select an order operation > Order Details
  • Capacity Scheduling Board app > Select an order operation > Operation Info

2. On  Capacity Scheduling Table: Extensibilities are allowed to adapt New Fields to be selected on Filters criteria and change the Layout of the worklist displayed by adding new additional information customized using business context: Master Data: Product General, Master Data: Product Plant, Order Master Data, Manufacturing: Planned Order Header and Production Orders: Variant Configuration

After adjustments you can follow the following Navigation Path to select your new custom Fields:

  • Capacity Scheduling Table app > Worklist Search filters > Adapt Filters // Flexible Column Layout > Additional Information
  • Capacity Scheduling Table app > Orders Table > Settings // Flexible Column Layout > Additional Information

-----

As part of this blog, I would like to share a Usage case where a customer wanted to personalize the Capacity Planning table to add new custom object for Characteristics used in Variant configuration to segregate the orders/operation displayed and prioritize some fo then to take leveling action in the right time.

------

The CPS application brings integration for business where Advanced Variant Configuration is in place, by allowing the Navigation to the Variant Configuration Screen to view the product configuration for the production orders (indicated by an icon).

In terms of extensibility, the Capacity Scheduling Table app is allowed to add characteristics since release OP2022 and in Cloud Editions, where planners can utilize characteristics from VC specific information to segregate the orders/operation listed and use characteristics as part of the filter criteria.

To achieve this is needed you use ‚ÄòManage Characteristics as Custom Fields‚Äô App

IMPORTANT NOTE :

As per SAP Note: 3220904 characteristic-based Field Extensibility (CFE) solution is redesigned, new business context is introduced (PRODUCTION_ORDER_CFE), where data load logic for characteristic-based custom fields has been optimized, and characteristic master data synchronization has been improved. Old business context (PP_ORD_CONFIGURATION_CFE) is marked as obsolete and should not be considered. BTW, This business Context is applicable as well to enhance Manage Production Orders

Now, after selecting Production Orders ‚Äì Variant Configuration: PRODUCTION_ORDER_CFE (AFPO) will display the details of the Business Context, where you can click on Edit, which will be allow changes in Draft mode to enable the addition and select de desired characteristic, as example we will select ‚ÄòLOBM_APO_SL_MIN‚Äô, add a Custom Field description ‚ÄòMin Shelf Life‚Äô and click on Save

After saving, the characteristic will be added to the custom Fields list, wait for some time to allow the system to publish, if needed you could use Refresh status for updates, and shortly the Characteristic change to Status ‚Äúready to use‚Äù, and at the same time checking back on the initial screen, all the business context were displayed, you should now see the new Consolidate status marked as ready to used

Now, to make ACV characteristic custom fields visible and usable in Capacity Scheduling Table app it is also required to extend source by opening Fiori app ‚ÄòCustom Field‚Äô app, and into the ‚ÄúData Source Extensions‚Äù and click on the plus button ‚Äò+‚Äù to add an extension of data source

A new pop-up window named New Data Source Extension will appear to insert, here you will add Data Source: PP_SCHEDULEPRODUCTION_SRV; Description: ZPP_SCHEDULEPRODUCTION_SRV (or desired), and Extension ID: ZPP_SCHEDULEPRODUCTI, the correlative will be automatically predefined and gray out. Once all is maintained you can select Create

This automatically will open a new Field Section to maintain the available field. Here you can extend the Field Path of Worklist Scheduling Products under Available Field Section, and select the characteristic added in the previous step, then click Save it and Publish.

Be aware that I have created previously another custom characteristic to refer to the Max Shelf Life in my scenario.

Now after refreshing the screen, you will see on the Data Source Extension List the Extension published

Finally, you are now able can navigate to Capacity Scheduling app and adapt the filters or modify the layout by modifying the view setting as needed!!!

Hope you find the example relevant to facilitate some of the custom requests on the application!!

Regards,

Jennifer!!

entry.title: Re: TIMEOUT dump (11 min.) for RFC in low priority (runti...

Please, check the SAP Note 2129291 - Session Priority and Work Process Quota in SAP Kernels >= 7.4x for details. Especially, it mentions that the priority inheritance concept takes place ('As background jobs run with low priority, any RFC sessions created as a result of background jobs making RFC calls will be created with low priority as well.'), should you need to run your RFC as low prio, start the main program as a background job.

entry.title: SAP AI Skills Gap Analysis: Are We Ready?
entry.content:
The SAP AI Skills Assessment results are out, and there's a fascinating exploration of the gaps and readiness across the globe. Since the initial publication, the dataset has grown from 68 to 141 responses spanning 10 countries. The study revalidates the 1.6-2.1 point gap between motivation and implementation across different geographies, identifying systemic challenges rather than measurement artifacts.

Key findings illustrate a persistent implementation challenge, an awareness trap, a governance thread, and a pronounced focus on S/4HANA. Though awareness and motivation are relatively high, actual implementation capabilities significantly lag behind, with only 6-17% of professionals globally ready to implement AI solutions.

The report suggests shifting the focus from awareness campaigns to hands-on enablement strategies to bridge this significant gap. To harness the high motivation levels, it recommends a detailed training and role-based learning path, along with practical implementation experiences. Visit the provided blog from Thomas Jenewein for an in-depth analysis and to view the complete results.

I am interested in hearing your thoughts on how organizations can effectively bridge the gap between high motivation for AI implementation and the actual skills required, ensuring that the enthusiasm for AI translates into real-world, impactful applications.  Please comment below.

entry.title: Technical AS-IS EA Canvas: Accelerating Assessments in Undocumented Environments
entry.content:
Introduction: The AS-IS Challenge in Clients Without Documentation

In Enterprise Architecture (EA) projects, the very first and most critical step is establishing an accurate AS-IS baseline. However, in many companies, formal documentation simply does not exist. Knowledge about applications, integrations, and infrastructure often lives only in the minds of employees.

In environments like this, trying to capture requirements directly into tools such as SAP LeanIX‚Äîor relying on long email threads‚Äîbecomes slow, inefficient, and error‚Äëprone.

To address this challenge and accelerate the Assessment phase, we developed and successfully applied the Technical AS-IS EA Canvas methodology.
You can access the methodology assets here:
üëâ link

The Solution: A Cognitive & Tactile Methodology Supported by AI

Our approach innovates by separating human interaction from metadata capture, using AI to produce high-fidelity insights from the workshop.

1. The Tactile and Visual Workshop (The Canvas)

The heart of the methodology is the Technical AS-IS EA Canvas, a large-format (A0/A1) printed board designed for collaborative mapping.

Key characteristics:

  • Structure: The Canvas visually separates the technology landscape into On-Premise, Cloud, and External, aligned with the TOGAF ADM phases.
  • Interaction: Participants use colored post-its (following ArchiMate patterns for Application, Technology, and Business) to map systems, while strings represent integration flows.
  • Capabilities: Tools like SAP Signavio Process Explorer are used during the session to anchor discussions and ensure the mapping reflects true business capabilities.

2. High-Fidelity Data Capture (Audio + AI)

The major differentiator of this methodology is how the technical metadata is captured:

  • Recording & Cognition: Instead of taking notes, the architect focuses on facilitating the session using a guided Cheat-Sheet. The entire session is recorded.
  • AI Synthesis: The audio is then processed by an AI engine that extracts the essential metadata:
    • protocols
    • integration frequency
    • triggers
    • pain points
    • non-functional requirements
    • security considerations
    • and other technical details often lost in traditional workshops

This ensures no insight is missed.

3. The Result: Structured Data Ready for SAP LeanIX

The combination of photo + audio + AI extraction produces a reliable and complete dataset.

  • Structured Output: AI produces clean, structured metadata from the discussion.
  • Direct Import: This dataset is formatted and imported into SAP LeanIX, feeding the EA repository with a high-confidence AS-IS.
  • Focus on To-Be: With the AS-IS complete, architects can move directly to Gap Analysis and To-Be Architecture, drastically accelerating the project lifecycle.

Conclusion

The Technical AS-IS EA Canvas methodology demonstrates how tactile, visual engagement combined with AI capabilities solves one of the biggest challenges in Enterprise Architecture: capturing knowledge in undocumented environments.

We were able to extract all relevant requirements, applications, and integration flows‚Äîbuilding a robust EA baseline in SAP LeanIX with confidence and speed.

This approach not only reduces risk but transforms the AS-IS assessment into an engaging, high-value experience for all participants.

What about you?

I would love to hear your experiences with AS-IS capture in undocumented environments.
How do you deal with missing documentation in EA projects?

Share your thoughts and let‚Äôs exchange best practices!

Transparency Note: This post was drafted with the assistance of an Artificial Intelligence model to ensure clarity and structure.

entry.title: Clean Core + SAP BTP ‚Äî The "Golden Ratio" for Utilities
entry.content:
• üî• Teaser: Clean Core + SAP BTP ‚Äî The "Golden Ratio" for Utilities üìà
  •  

Stop thinking of a "Clean Core" as a technical constraint. Start thinking of it as the launchpad for everything else.

In my work across real-world utility transformations, the truth is simple:

 

‚Ä¢ Clean Core = Stability.

‚Ä¢ SAP BTP = Innovation.

‚Ä¢ Together = Sustainability. If you are still modifying the core to meet new regulatory demands, you aren't building a foundation; you‚Äôre building a cage. You need an architecture that allows you to move fast without risking the "Engine Room."

 

The Big Question: How do you modernize without disrupting mission-critical billing, metering, and customer processes?

 

I‚Äôm dropping a deep dive soon on how SAP Build, Event Mesh, and AI Core create the decoupled, event-driven architecture modern utilities actually need to thrive.

 

Don't let your legacy code hold your future hostage. üí°
